Name: Le Tour de Piste
Description: French indoor cycling game that won a price at the Concours Lépine International in Paris. The board is quite large, measuring 81x51 cm. and the box contains 6 teams with 4 wooden cyclists and a dernyrider (generic for a small pacing motorcycle and rider used in cycle races). There also is a pawn to count the game turns and there are 8 cards to determine the starting order.

Name: Day Trip Rhode Island
Description: Players travel throughout the state of Rhode Island, answering trivia questions and collecting four specific postcards before returning to the central post office.

Name: Trivial Pursuit: Kansallispainos
Description: This is expansion card set for Trivial Pursuit: Genus Edition. Kansallispainos is Finnish and it just means national edition. So here you have 250 cards with 1500 questions about Finland and matters concerning Finnish people. Of course the questions and answers are in Finnish.

Name: Défifoo Orange: Conquête du Monde
Description:
Conquer the world by building house on the 7 continents. Place is limited and soon you'll have to build on top of the other player's houses. Will you try to burn their house, have lightning fall on their houses?

Once all cards have been placed, each continent is counted, the player who has the majority on the continent wins the continent, the player who wins the most continents is the winner.

Name: Die Maus: Mit Köpfchen
Description:
Die Maus - Mit Köpfchen is a fast childrens word guessing game.

One player turns over one of 33 cards showing terms like 'A meal with...', 'A toy with...', 'A pet with...'. Then he rolls 6 dice. 5 dice (each with a different color) show letters. The sixth die is a colored die that indicates which of the letter dice is to be used. If it shows the white color any player can choose any rolled letter die he wants. Now all players simultaneously try to guess a word corresponding to the term on the card that starts with the rolled letter. The first players that finds a word gets the card as prize.

The game stops when all cards are won by the players. The player with the most cards wins the game.

Name: Gratuity Not Included
Description:
Gratuity Not Included is a fast paced card game placed in a restaurant during the Friday night rush.  Each player grabs their server’s apron, a stack of menus and their handy notepad to seat patrons and fill orders.
  
A player's section of the restaurant has a number of tables depending on game length.  Patrons are placed on the tables and wait for service.  Players must play food and drink cards on patrons according to their tastes.  When orders are filled the patron will ‘tip’ a portion of the meal cost to the player.
 The goal is to get the most tips.

Gratuity Not Included is currently in Alpha rules development and playtesting.

Name: Reader's Digest Word Power
Description:
This board game from Reader's Digest puts your knowledge of words to the test in your quest to become the Word Power champion. But watch out - Wild Cards, Power Cards or the roll of the dice will move you along, set you back or even help foil your opponents.

Contents:
Game Board
700 Challenge Cards (2100 challenges in total)
50 Power Cards
30 Wild Cards
6 game pieces
1 dice and dice-throwing cup

Name: High School Musical 3 CD Board Game
Description: It's Senior Year at East High. Join the High School Musical gang as they face their hopes, dreams and their fears on the way to the graduation stage. Along the way players answer trivia questions and sing & dance a bit. The interactive music game CD adds to the fun! All packed in a neat portfolio case. For 2 or more players Ages 7 and up

Name: Fairy-opoly
Description:
From the back cover:

"Fairy-opoly is a game that allows imaginations to flutter and soar! Players collect fairy friends, give those fairies a pair of wings, and collect acorns each time another player lands on their space. Oh, the friends that can be made!

"Sprinkle your pretend fairy dust and advance to Twinkle. Enter a world of lively little fairies with positive messages to share. There is magic in believing! You two can be a fairy!"

The game ends the moment one person goes broke.

Name: Fairy Finds Game
Description:
From the enclosed instructions:

Players (both readers and non-readers) work together in this co-operative game, using a combination of luck and simple strategy to help the fairies build a Fairy Ring. As with all fine fairy tales, there lurks a tricky troll in the background who would rather take over the beautiful Fairy Ring site for himself. A roll of the die can work in his favor, so players must figure out a strategy, using the fairy cards, to foil both the troll and lady luck.

Name: Summer Heights High
Description:
Based on the Australian television show, in Summer Heights High: the popularity board game players must try to earn the most popularity points. Popularity points are used as a form of currency to claim (or purchase) school spaces, such as the cafeteria or classrooms. Other players are then charged points if they land on a place that has been claimed.

Players can also be sent to detention and can pick fights with other players to claim territory (decided by rolling the die).

The game is clearly a simplified version of Monopoly, with paper "popularity points" instead of money.

Name: Ombagassische Würfelmagie
Description: The game consists of 12 large dice and some chips. There are rules for six games included, four of which are solitaire games. Some are reminiscent of "Rubik's Cube", just with separate dice.

Name: Blood & Steel: Expansion
Description:
From the publisher's website:

The Blood & Steel Expansion Pack is designed by Paul Rohrbaugh and is an extension of the highly successful Blood & Steel folio game on the battle of Kursk.

The Expansion Pack involves the two other pivotal battles around the Kursk salient: Oboyan Hills and Rzhavets bridgehead using the Blood & Steel game system.

Expands:

    Blood & Steel

Name: Ponyri-Kursk: The Northern Pincers July 7 & 8, 1943
Description:
From the publisher's website:

Ponyri-Kursk: The Northern Pincers July 7 & 8, 1943 is a stand-alone Blood & Steel system game designed by Paul Rohrbaugh and is an extension of the highly successful Blood & Steel folio game on the battle of Kursk.

Ponyri Station is a simulation of the armored clashes between XLI Panzer Corps and the defending Soviet forces near the small town of Ponyri, reflecting the high water mark of the German Kursk campaign.

Expands:

    Blood & Steel (but ownership is not necessary to play).


Game Scale:
Game Turn: 2 hours
Hex: .75 miles / 1.21 kilometers
Units: Company to Reigment

Game Inventory:
One 11 x 17" full color map
One dual-side printed countersheet (176 5/8" counters)
One 8-page rulebook
One game folder/player aid chart

Solitaire Playability: High
Complexity Level: Medium
Players: 2 or more
Playing Time: 1-2 hours

Note: Players will need to provide one 6-sided die for game play.

Name: Jungle Life DVD game
Description:
Sequel to the popular "Wildlife DVD Boardgame".

The setting has moved from the Serengeti to the jungle.
The concept of the game remains the same though: Answer trivia questions related to the video fragments on the DVD. But there are a few minor changes. Up to 6 people can play now, 5 Questions must be answered each round, to determine the number of spaces you can move. 2 "Danger-plates" are added.

From the publisher's website:
In this exciting DVD board game, players help their chimpanzee make his way through a jungle full of danger. Every player has his or her own chimpanzee. Answer the trivia questions correctly and You can help save your chimpanzee and his friends' jungle home.

Jungle Life can be played with entire family and was developed in collaboration with National Geographic

Name: Breakout at St. Lo
Description:
Published in Panzer Digest #5.

Simulates the American breakout at the start of Operation: Cobra in the bocage country of France, in the month after D-Day.   Americans are on the offensive, and must destroy German units and exit the map to the south; Germans are on the defensive, and must try and prevent this.

Name: Thunder Gods: Kamikazes at Okinawa
Description:
Game uses a standard deck of cards to resolve activations and combat between the Japanese planes trying to destroy US Navy ships, and the American planes and ships in defense.  Simulation of kamikaze action off Okinawa in April, 1945.

Published in Panzer Digest #5

Name: My Little Ladybug
Description: Full title is My Little LadyBug Fly Away Home game. Players try to be the first to collect three different colored baby bug chips for their ladybug house. A plastic ladybug acts as a spinner when placed on top of each player's flower base as well as a device which shoots out the chips when her head is pressed. No reading required. Ages 3 - 6.

Name: Tannhäuser Field Ops
Description:
Tannhäuser Field Ops is a table top card game where the cards move on the table (like in Wings of War and Battleground) to represent various units in the 1949 Tannhäuser U-Chronic Universe where WWI never ended and the Reich has uncovered eldritch horror and the forces of the Union under President Edison are benefitting from alien technology from the Roswell UFO crash.

The player each secretly set up their orders and then play out the turn. Troops are assisted by various gear and special powers and are affected by different terrain cards on the table. Defeat the enemy troops or complete a scenario conditions to win.

Name: Tannhäuser: Daedalus
Description:
Somewhere in Crete, buried under the ruins of the Palace of Knossos lay fantastic secrets hidden and trapped by the famous Labyrinth of Minos. You send in your commando squad to uncover the secrets, but find a dark winding complex of tunnels filled with enemy soldiers. You must fight or die!

Daedalus is the second expansion map for TannhÃ¤user. It introduces the Labyrinth of Minos where you will explore the maze made famous by the Minotaur of Minos; filled with mystery and great treasure.

Daedalus introduces several new concepts to TannhÃ¤user maps. Included are one way spaces, restricted spaces and 4 entry points! There is also a horizontal tram system to speed a single character's across to the opposite side of the map. There is also a series of 6 scenarios and 64 tokens featuring many of the Token of the Month entries.

Name: The Shopping Game
Description:
Simple economics for children aged from 8 (although most 5 year olds can play the game well).

Move around the store buying the cheapest item of clothing (from 8 different types) but don't spend more than £25 (it is an old game!).

Name: Sea and Sand
Description:
Roll a dice to select the size (small, medium or large) tile randomly chosen from the face down pile to place on the playing board.

The tile placed must have a common edge to a tile already played and bonus points are available if the placed tile has an animal depicted.

Covering other symbols on the board also generate bonus points (so an early introduction to tactical play).

Unplayable pieces count as minus points at the end of the game.

Part of the "Let's Play" series from Crown Andrews.

Name: Shepherd
Description:
Co-operative game playing for very young children.

From the rules:
"Paul, the Shepherd, has spent the day tending his sheep and lambs. He was helped by his dogs. As evening approached and it was time to bring the sheep and lambs into a pen for the night, Paul busied himself with putting the logs together for the pen while the dogs rounded up the sheep and lambs. It was a game they all enjoyed. The dogs hurried about trying to get the sheep and lambs into the pen before Paul could lay all the logs together to close the two entrances. See if you can help so the dogs can win again."

The players try to drive home the sheep by using their dogs. They have to achieve this before the shepherd completes a pen in the middle of the game area (which is variably set up from tiles, some of which are the sheep). The building speed is determined by the same die that also moves the dogs which can proceed to the next tile of the color that was rolled. As so often with Herder games, players can pass their die results to other players. All players win or lose together (if the pen is completed before the sheep are in).

Game play is varied by the fact that the meadow is completed by the forming of paths using 28 interlocking tiles that feature the sheep, poppies, etc. The number of tiles can be reduced to make the game easier for younger children.

Name: Triage
Description:
Triage is a wonderful card game from the French publisher Grimaud who is more well known for his releases of traditional card games.
Aim of the game is to complete special trains and to score points for the best and longest of them.
This is done basically by drafting and discarding.
But what separates it from other games which are similar is a spinner with French train signals which will enhance or hinder your basic draw.
And you can steal an opponents train if you complete it using a set number of additional cards.

Game components are of the finest sort: Super illustrated cards with locos and train cars from the steam area (featuring the famous Bugatti train...) before WW II and a patented card tray with golden applications.

Name: The Ukraine on Fire: French Debacle at Odessa 1919
Description:
WW1 had barely ended when the Allies began to interfere with the Russian Civil War in 1918. France, eager to continue flexing its military muscle, sent troops to colonize and control the Ukraine region while disarming the German troops there. The local population welcomed them to some degree thinking the French and Greek troops were sent to liberate them from the Red menace. Armed with tanks, aircraft and armor cars, the French sent the Greeks out to remote areas to secure it. However, the Red followers had secured vast amounts of weapons from the Germans, much to the dislike of the French, and were more than eager to fight. By March 1919, the Ukraine was on fire. The French and Greek troops were greatly disliked by all Russians after their true intentions had been revealed to the general public. This further emboldened the Red forces who were outnumbering the Allies. In the coming weeks, numerous battles were fought until the last bastion at Odessa.

Game using the 'Russian Civil War Series' system.

Game components:

•One 11" x 17" map sheet depicting the terrain the battle was fought over.
•One sheet of 260 counters.
•One Players’ Aid Sheet.
•The series core rulebook that include the game rules used.
•A rulebook specific to The Ukraine on Fire.

Name: MegaMusic
Description:
The game mechanics is based on the one of Monopoly, but with quite a few noticeable additions. Moving around the board players may buy festival sites, build stages, trade rare recordings, hire artists, make new recordings, etc. Added inner track - so called "The wheel of fortune" adds another dimension of players' interaction to the mix: here players may release new songs, collect awards for them, making them go to top10 etc. The game money depict famous musicians like Jimmy Hendrix or Elvis Presley. 
The game is accompanied with a four compact disc compilation of Polish music.

Name: Scene It? To Go!: Movie
Description:
All the fun of the original game is packed into these compact travel cases with on-screen trivia cards and dice! Magnetic game tokens make it possible to play Scene It? anytime, anywhere.

The compact travel case features real movie clips, trivia questions and on-screen challenges from Hollywood's hottest films, including Titanic, There's Something About Mary, Fargo and more!

Name: Monopoly: Turku
Description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

Another version of Monopoly, this time based on the city of Turku (Swedish name Åbo), Finland.

Name: Monopoly: West Coast Eagles Football Club Charity Edition
Description:
An officially licenced Monopoly edition published to raise money for the Western Australian charity organisation 'Telethon'.
The streets are replaced with colour photos of the greatest players and coaches of the AFL (Australian Football League) West Coast Eagles Football Club 1989-2007.

Name: The Great Australian Road Trip
Description:
A Trivia Game about Australian people, places, wildlife and events across Australia.
Players answer trivia questions, choosing between questions marked as Easy, Medium or Hard, moving 2, 4 or 6 places respectively if they get the answers correct.
Victory is achieved by traveling to three randomly selected destinations across Australia and correctly answering a multiple choice trivia question there, plus by collecting three 'Detour' tokens along the way by achieving 'Detour' quests in their travels.
To even out the game there are 'Half & Half' cards which remove one of the wrong multiple choice answers at the destinations, and 'Speed' cards which allow you to move even if you get an answer wrong. These can be given in greater numbers to younger (or non-Australian) players.

Name: E, the Game of Martian Chinese Checkers
Description:
E, the Game of Martian Chinese Checkers (E = mc² - get it?) requires one Icehouse stash per player and a specifically laid out hex board.  The board is a large hexagon, with its six sections colored to match the pyramids that will go on it - consistent with Chinese Checkers.  The line of hexes that forms the border between "home" territories is multi-colored, matching the adjacent home territories.  What makes E special is that it uses the natural size stackability of the Icehouse pieces to enhance Chinese Checkers significantly.  For one thing, pieces must move precisely as many steps and/or jumps as they have pips (i.e. Smalls go 1; mediums, 2; larges, 3).

The major effect on play comes from the stackability.

     A piece may never - not even for a step of a move - stack directly on its own color.  (except as the result of a guard exchange)
     If you can physically touch your piece (without shifting things about), you may move it, even if that means pieces atop it will take a free ride.
     If you can't physically touch your piece, it is trapped.
     You may never trap a piece in its home territory.  The multicolor hexes come into play here, creating a somewhat safe zone for pieces.  The center space is safe for everyone.
     You may liberate a trapped piece of yours, teleport a guard (a trapping piece of yours), and violate the "never stack directly on yourself" rule by performing a guard exchange.


The game is otherwise exactly like Chinese Checkers.

Game System

    Icehouse Pieces

Name: Totem Blocks
Description:
Players take turns stacking wooden blocks that are cut in odd shapes.  Take advantage of the irregular shapes to interlock blocks and stack them in a high tower.
From package: "Fun to play alone or with friends also taking turns.  If you stack all the blocks without them falling you're top man on the TOTEM POLE."

Ages 3 and up.

Name: Caravaneers
Description:
A desert themed abstract played on a 7x7 board.  Players try to move the pieces (Caravaneers) using two types of movement choices from their start position on the "North" and "West" edges of the board through the desert and safely to their Caravanserai located on either the "East" edge of the board or the "South" edge of the board.  The player who has captured (collected) more Caravaneers by the end of play is the winner.

Online Play


     Super Duper Games

Name: Chicane
Description: In a hand of Chicane, each of the  Decktet cards is treated as just having one suit. For the double-suited number cards, only the top or bottom suit is active in a given hand. Players bid to determine which it will be.

Name: Wine Fluency
Description:
New Kickstarter for Wine Fluency - find us there!

In Wine Fluency you collaborate, compete and drink wine! The other teams try to guess what characteristics of the wine the pouring team has chosen. Everyone discusses the wine and then teams take turns choosing cards that match what they feel will best match the pouring teams decisions. Unlike many wine games, this is not a trivia game where you are asked questions; You only need to place your marker on the game board to indicate the following questions: Where is it from? What's the grape? How old is it? How high is the alcohol? Naturally, you have to guess. Whoever guesses best gets the most points for the bottle, and you play as many bottles as there are teams.

This game is a blast and wines is always great!

Name: Erotic Adventure
Description: A player draws a card and moves forward on the game board to the nearest space that matches the color on the card.  The player then performs the action corresponding to the color on the body part shown on the space.  The first player to reach the end wins.

Name: Herken de Hits
Description:
Players attempt to recognize very short music fragments from all periods in modern and classical music. Every game 50 songs have to be identified and written down on the scoresheet.

Comes with a CD with 495 fragments. Can be played individually or in teams.

Name: Samkvæmisspil Baggalúts
Description:
This party game is included with the Icelandic band Baggalútur's 2008 album - Nýjasta Nýtt.

The board is a simple track of 46 circles in yellow, red, green and blue, starting at Home Base and ending at Late Party. Roll a dice and move the pawn (not included, but the band suggests using coins, nuts, earrings, cuffs or very patient insects) along the track. When the player lands on a red, green or blue circle roll the dice twice and follow the rules accordingly.

The first player to Late Party wins the game.

Name: Galloping Bowling
Description: Galloping Bowling is a rather rare Bakelite collectible dice game most likely manufactured in the early 1940s by Galloping Games, Inc.. The game consists of five catalin dice with faces depicting pins with numbers representing the number of knocked down pins or a special marking such as spare (/), strike (X) or split (O).  As in standard "lane bowling", the dice game is played by rolling dice twice for each frame and uses a similar scoring sheet to regulation bowling. Another game by the same publisher already included on Board Game Geek is the more available "Galloping Golf".

Name: Scrabble: 2007 Boston Red Sox Worlds Series Championship Edition
Description:
From the box: "Can you spell SWEEP? How about WORLD SERIES CHAMPIONS? America's Favorite Word Game meets New England's most celebrated sports franchise in the 2007 Boston Red Sox World Series Championship Edition of SCRABBLE. It's the same classic SCRABBLE played on a baseball diamond featuring great commemorative 2007 World Series images and stats. Baseball shaped letter tiles, some ultra fun rules and a special Red Sox World Series bonus dictionary is sure to be a grand slam!"

One of several Major League Baseball editions of Scrabble licensed and published by Sababa Toys. The most significant difference in this game is the way the board is laid out to resemble a baseball diamond, meaning the location of bonus squares is significantly different from classic Scrabble.

Name: John Lewis Gender Wars
Description: A team game where the players are divided into teams by gender. Each team gets a deck of cards with a category printed on it and five answers (words), the deck of cards for each team contains subjects that are stereotypically associated with that gender. The category is read out, the timer is started and the other team writes down up to eight answers on a pad. Once time runs out, the team writing gets one point for every word that was on the card, the other team then gets a card read to them, and after eight rounds the team with the most points win.

Name: Mini World Cup Soccer
Description:
"The Original Board Game of International Soccer Competition"

You run an entire soccer team as they work their way through a tournament.  The object is to win enough games and enough money to advance through the tournament rounds to the Champion round, and then win the final match to capture the Mini Gold Cup.

Name: Gotta Getta Gopher
Description:
Knock the gopher from his hole.
To knock them all, is your goal!

Contents:
1 Green Game Base with Transparent Game Cover, 2 Shooters, 16 Gophers and 40 Balls.

Each player has 8 gophers which are placed into holes in the game base. They then simultaneously launch balls out of the shooters aiming for the ramps beneath their opponent's gophers to knock them out from their holes. The first player to knock out all gophers wins. For advanced play, each player has a "wild" gopher with a black cap which may be placed in any hole and must be the last gopher knocked out to win.

Name: Who Gets It?
Description: Game to help with reading readiness.  Players match image with words.  For preschool to first grade students.

Name: Match
Description: Players match cards containing words and pictures.  An educational game for 1st grade elementary students.

Name: Blast from the Past
Description:
From the box:

Which prophet was named one of the most admired men in the world?  Did the Hill Cumorah Pageant start before or after the 100th anniversary of the organization of the Church?  When did LDS gymnast Peter Vidmar lead the U.S. men's gymnastics team to its first-ever Olympic gold medal?

You don't need to know the exact date; just fit each event into your time line.  Be the first to put your ten cards in chronological order and you win!

Name: Cheater's Game
Description:
Cheater’s Game is a simple competitive game with a straightforward goal: End the tenth round with the highest score. Your score consists of two types of points: honest points and points you have from cheater’s alliances. Honest points are completely risk-free, but they’re harder to accumulate. Cheater’s alliance points are easy to accumulate, and accumulate faster when you have many players in your alliance. However, any member of an alliance can turn the other members of the alliance in and take the alliance's points, adding them to their honest score. So the question is, “How far you trust a group of self-admitted cheaters?”

Cheater’s Game uses about five standard six-sided dice, two point trackers, a turn tracker, player score pawns, and several sets of cheater’s alliance pawns.  The trackers and pawns you need to play are all available as a 284 KB PDF.

Cheater’s Game has fairly simple rules, but complex psychosocial dynamics. You could play it with children as young as 6 or 7, and use it as a tool for teaching ethical and social lessons. Cheater’s Game is appropriate for Ages 12 and up without adult supervision. A 4-player game takes about 45 minutes to play.

Name: Buck Fever
Description: Roll a die and move your hunter on the game board.  Try to collect animals while dealing with various situation cards.

Name: Realms of War
Description:
Realms of War is a game of fantasy battlefields, of monsters, soldiers and magic. Players take the roles of commanders of huge armies in a game that’s never played the same way twice, even if players use the same army over and over again.

In Realms of War, cards represent units, commanders, magic, random events and terrain.  The key to the game is not only getting the right cards at the right time, but playing them at the right time much like a general must recognize and take advantage of his opportunities.

Unlike other card games that represent fantasy battles, there are no contrived effects or cutesy, gamey rules.  Realms of War plays like a real, epic battle with units, flanks and tactics.  There are no cards to collect as Realms of War is NOT a CCG; each set contains everything you need to immediately begin fighting fantasy battles.

One of the big attractions of this game is the free, downloadable armies from several popular fantasy genres such as D&D, Warhammer, Dragonlance and coming soon - Middle Earth!

Available at http://biagamesonline.tripod.com

Name: Défifoo Jaune
Description:
The aim of the game is to be the first to get ride of all your cards.
Each player must place a higher card than the card already played. If he can't he has to pick a card from the draw pile.
Yellow cards are stronger than green cards and red cards are stronger then yellow cards
Red >> Yellow >> Green
There are three symbols:
Rock >>(breaks)>> Scissor >>(cut)>> Paper >>(wrap)>> Rock
There are also jokers cards (three colors), Skull-and-crossbones cards that can never be played, for a chance to win you must get ride of it.
There are also event cards.

Name: Rugged Adventures
Description:
Frome the website:

Rugged Adventures is a unique approach to table top miniatures gaming. It is a mixture of skirmish wargaming and roleplaying. While must you command bodies of figures as in any miniature wargame you also play at least one character represented by a miniature on the playing surface (or set to use an appropriate movie term). This Player Represented Personality or PRP is required to act in accordance with a pre-determined character design, complete with special abilities, specific quirks, personal goals and a requirement for the gamer to take on all the characteristics they find attached to their particular miniature.

It is a light hearted approach to tabletop games with a strong emphasis on fun and story-telling. The Rugged Adventures player is encouraged not to win the game but play the story. Often players are required by the GM to act up their actions or give an 'in character' verbal account of themselves. We want our players to laugh, shout, speak in silly accents and generally come away from a game having enjoyed themselves whether they won or lost.

If I had to boil the design philosophy down to the essentials: Rugged Adventures is a game for those of us who love to build models, terrain and paint lots of figures-and still want to have a fast paced and fun game that doesn’t bog down with complex detail. Think of the Pulp Genre itself, action oriented story telling where glaring holes in the plot are often an advantage, and then apply this same spirit to the table-top.

Name: Jeu des Touristes
Description: Vintage French cycling game from the 1910's with metal riders. The oldest version of the board had the games' rules printed on the board. It featured a Zeppelin on one of the corners (all the drawings in the corners were different, in fact), and a pre-Weimar Republic flag in a militarized Germany. The later version has demilitarized the German border, but not the Atlantic coast, which is still heavily armed.

Name: Symposion
Description:
"A Symposion is a Greek word meaning a Wine drinking party. These were popular in ancient Greece. Depending on the Host (Symposiarch), the emphasis of the gathering could range from purely Intellectual discussion to Hedonistic debauchery."

The players score points by hosting a Symposion. This is done by playing a set of cards and declaring whether the Symposion is intellectual, social, or hedonistic. The type of Symposion determines how points are calculated for the particular cards played.

The game ends when the deck has been gone through three times and no player has a Symposion to play. The player with the most points wins the game.

Name: Guelph & Ghibelline
Description:
"Factional Warfare within and between the City States of  Northern Italy circa 1220-1380. Each player takes the role of a Faction that can be found in any given city." The five player factions are: Papalists, Imperialists, Republicans, Signorialists, and Citizenry.

The game is played on a circular track made up of 26 spaces. Each space represents a city in Northern Italy and is marked with the name of the city. Victory Tokens are earned by establishing control over cities.

"The Player with the most Victory Tokens at the end of the game wins. The game ends after 30 Rounds."

Name: Space Freighter
Description:
"Card game for 2-4+ players. Space Trading Theme. Deliver goods to far flung worlds for mega credits."

The players share a common deck made up of four types of cards: Goods, Worlds, Events, and Aid.

Mega Credits are earned by delivering Goods to Worlds. This is done by one World card and one or more Goods cards.

Event cards are resolved immediately when drawn. Aid cards can be discarded to avoid negative Event cards.

"The player with the most Mega Credits (MC) at the end of the game wins."

Name: Le Criterium des As
Description: French cycling game from the '50s. It contains a board (with almost 600 squares) and 7 cyclists (6 in national colors and 1 with a yellow jersey).

Name: Tour de Francia
Description: Spanish cycling game about the Tour de France produced at the end of the 1950's with artwork by Lizarraga.

Name: Jeu des Bicyclistes
Description: Old French game published in Paris with a cycling theme. The French Musée National de l'éducation has a copy of it on display.

Name: Bauer sucht Frau: Das Brettspiel
Description: Bauer sucht Frau - das Brettspiel is based on the successful German TV show "Bauer sucht Frau" in which real German farmers are looking for a partner. In the boardgame you have the same goal of finding a partner. You draw a profile card and move with your potential partner to your farm. The game is featuring trivia questions as well as communicative tasks. Whoever collected enough love markers first, will win the game and get married.

Name: Sportmagazin
Description: DDR board game featuring multiple sports like cycling and gymnastics.

Name: Von Drahtesel zur Rennmaschine
Description: Motorcycling game with simple roll & move mechanics.

Name: Giro d'Italia Ciclo-Automobilistico
Description: Double purposed Italian game from Milan published in the '60s. A simple roll and move game played with bikes or cars on the same track (Giro d'Italia). A cycling race and a car race can be played on the same board. The cycling game features three teams of two riders (whereas the car race features 6 independent cars) and the race consists of eight stages, including a time-trial. Points are awarded to the first three riders in each stage, but not all the stages award the same number of points.

Name: Le Tour Cycliste
Description: French cycling game released at the end of the '90s.

Name: Maglia Rosa
Description: Italian cycling game. The board is divided in two halves, one of which is common and the other is different for each stage. You can run several Giro stages or a Milan-San Remo. Every player chooses his favorite cyclist that's available, each with his own individual features. Some of the options are Fausto Coppi, Eddy Merckx, Bernard Hinault or Miguel Indurain. The game does not use a dice but instead an energy-keeping table and some chance cards.

Name: Recordman
Description: French game published in the '70s that combines a cycling game with geography. There was a version for 2 players only and a 4 player version published. Goal is to try to get from one city to another as fast as possible and the path is marked with pins, the board has a map of France.

Name: Tour de France Cycliste
Description: French cycling game about the Tour de France published in the 1960's in which you make your own circuit with big plastic pieces. The game also has four plastic cyclists.

Name: Game of Life: The Wizard of Oz
Description:
(From back of the box)

Travel along the Yellow Brick Road with your favorite characters from The Wizard of Oz: Dorothy, Scarecrow, Cowardly Lion and Tin Man. Experience The Wizard of Oz as you steal an apple, get caught by the Wicked Witch of the West, visit the Wizard of Oz and ultimately find your way home. Visit all of the magical locations like the poppy fields, Emerald City and Munchkinland in a quest to return to Auntie Em's Farmhouse with the most money and win the game.

Name: Pirate-opoly
Description: Heavily-stripped-down monopoly variant for children, box recommends Ages 5 - 8.  Pirate theme.

Name: Obama!  The Game
Description:
In Obama! the game, each player is attempting to win over the United States during the election of 2008 to be Obama!  There are seven state cards that vary between one and three points.  To win a state card, each player must build campaigns based on four areas: political, charisma, financial, and media.  When a campaign reaches the cost of the state in each of the four categories, the player wins the state.  In the end of the game, the player with the most state points wins.

Additional cards include "Yes We Can" cards featuring special abilities to secretly build a campaign and steal an opponent's state, or take a major supporter from their campaign.

Each card features vibrant colors, punchy political satire, and comical illustrations.  Cards include: Hill Re-Clinton Endorsement, Paylin Botches another interview, Win over Bill O'really, and the Two-Headed Stewart Colbert Media Beast!

Home Page: http://www.obamacardgame.com/

Name: Kingdom Quoor
Description:
From the Back of the Box:

Amass your Royal Warriors and rally your camp.  You have been granted the honor of defending Kingdom Quoor from the vile dragon scourge and rescuing her fair maidens.

Seek the sometimes costly aid of the citizens enlist the unique talents of the friar, the assassin, the wizard, the temptress and, more.

Bid for control and plot your every move, help your cause or hinder your opponents.

The many decisions are yours.

Temper your forces before entering a lair.  Slay the beasts and collect your rewards.

Tactful competition or purposeful sabotage.  Race against your vile opponents to prevail.

Experience the menace and marvel of Kingdom Quoor.

Name: Game of 31
Description:
A normal deck of cards is used. All the aces through sixs are removed and placed into their appropriate stacks. Players take turns removing one card and keeping a running total of the pips. The first player to take a card that makes the running total go past 31 loses!

This is an old con man's game. Con men have spent years studying the game to get some easy money. If you are offered a game of 31 from a complete and total stranger, don't take it... you're not going to win!

Name: Loose Change
Description: Loose Change is a card game of counting money. On their turn, players add to the cards face down in the middle, trying to add up to a dollar. If you complete the dollar, you earn the cards. But be careful not to bust--- for if you do, these cards count as negative points! Whoever has the most positive piles at the end is the winner.

Name: Le Tour de France de Pif
Description:
Simple French cycling game about 'Pif le Chien', published in 1960.

The players roll and move their pawns along the board using a spiral track. It's a Game of Goose like game. There are 74 spaces. Some of the spaces give players an advantage while other give a disadvantage. The first player arriving at space 74 wins the game.

Name: Tour de France: Spannend Wielerronde-spel
Description: Dutch cycling game about the Tour de France, published during WWII.

Name: Peloton
Description: Spanish cycling game from the '90s with a reversible board, trivia cards and a peloton counter, that moves one space at a time.

Name: Goldbärchen-Spiel
Description: In this game, players try to collect bear tiles with four different kinds of ribbons. The players move their playing pieces across the board and flip over the face down tile they end their move on. If they don't own the respective color yet, they get to keep it, otherwise they have to place it on the board again. Whoever collects all four colors first, wins.

Name: Golf
Description: Golf has two parts: A luck-based starting phase in which the players try do get their golf ball onto the green by rolling dice, and a dexterity phase on the green in which a mechanical golfer statue pushes the ball into the hole (for this, you have to press down the shoulders and then let go, and the golfer will hit the ball with a corresponding strength).

Name: Hans im Glück
Description: Based on a Fairy Tale (Hans im Glück) in which an allegedly naive man swaps his belongings into less and less valuable items, players try to follow a certain order of trades (gold into a horse, a horse into a cow, a cow into a pig etc.). This is done by moving over a layout of 30 face down tiles by help of a die roll. The players move to a tile, flip it over and see if it matches their needs. In the beginning, it is pure luck, later there is a memory aspect to the game.

Name: Hipp Hipp Hurra
Description: The game consists of 48 cards with 8 different, but similar faces. One is in the middle of the table. Players then take turns to flip open a card from their personal stack. The first player to discover two of the same faces calls "Hipp Hipp" and puts the two cards in front of him/her. If a player discovers three of the same (two in front of another player, one in the middle), he/she calls Hipp Hipp Hurra and wins that trio. Whoever has most trios in the end, wins.

Name: Im Zauberwald
Description: Bears move towards their home, courtesy of a color die. On the way, they are collecting magic items and have to watch out for an evil sorcerer who might turn these into useless flowers. Luck-based game for smaller kids.

Name: "Erst sehen - dann gehen!"
Description:
Each player moves one of his/her four meeples toward a meeting point while paying attention to the traffic signs on the way. Afterward, there is an intermediate game phase where the players need to sort some cards by their numbers. Finally, the meeples have to return home, again watching for the traffic signs.
The game is obviously designed to let children learn the traffic signs.

Name: Familie Mayer
Description: Collection of four luck-based games around a family doing various kinds of sports. In the "main game", each player has several cards of one family member and has to get complete families doing the same sport by asking other players about their hand cards, much like in the German classic "Quartett".

Name: Filou
Description: This is a memory game in which players move around a board which contains twelve face down chips (four sets of three each). Each time a meeple steps onto a square, the player shows the other side and places it onto the square he or she came from. The memory layout thus changes constantly. If a player knows the location of a complete set, he or she calls it (and gets the set if he or she is correct). New chips are placed and a new turn starts. Whoever collects 15 chips first, wins.

Name: Flieg, kleiner Schmetterling!
Description: Players move their butterflies from flower to flower and eventually try to reach the other side of the game board. Movement is determined by dice rolls. The flowers can actually moved in the course of the game.

Name: Gartenhüpfer
Description: A game for very young children. Each kid moves its meeple through a garden, trying to get rid of vegetable cards. When a card is drawn, the player moves 1 to 3 squares, depending on the number of vegetables on the card. Moves can be blocked by other players or the edge of the board, in which case no card can be used. Whoever can get rid of all cards first, wins.

Name: Don't Lose Your Head
Description:
Be the first person to place 4 pieces in a row.

This spin and place Whitman game from 1971 was made for 2 to 4 players Ages 4 - 8.

Games comes with 24 pieces (playing heads) in 4 colors (blue,red, yellow and orange), a game platform and a spinner.

Name: Banana Tree
Description:
There's a bunch of bananas up the tree and lots of little monkeys all in a spin!  You'll never know 'em, but they'll all fall down, and the big hungry ape is sure to win!"

The object of the game is to use the big ape to try and catch the monkeys as they fall out of the tree while trying to get to the bananas.

Includes Base, Tree, Ape, Ring, Spinner, and 19 monkeys.

For Ages 3 - 6

Name: Over The Top
Description:
Over The Top by Whitman Publishing Co. of Racine Wisconsin.

To play this game the player places the wooden shooter at any point behind the starting line and puts a ball in the cup. He then snaps the base of the shooter with his thumb and finger so the shooter slides down the playing board and hits the wooden barrier, making the ball jump out of the cup, over the barrier and into one of the numbered holes. To determine who shall play first, the players each snap one ball. The player having the highest score shoots first. Each player in turn then shoots all the balls. He adds the numbers appearing near the holes into which his balls fell. This is his score. 500 points wins the game.

Name: Know America
Description:
KNOW AMERICA Electric Game old WIRY DAN Toy by Harret Gilmar.

This trivia type game about knowing about America has a number of questions sheets with a choice of answers, By touching the correct answer you complete a circuit and a light goes on showing you that you have answered the question properly.

Name: Skeezix
Description:
Skeezix a game of Skeezix and his friends. A Rollicking Card Game from Milton Bradley.

A game for any number of players from 2 to 8.

There are four suits of 11 cards designated as follows: Gasoline - Red, Alley - Yellow, Back Fence - Blue and Tin Can - Black. The cards are numbered 1 to 11.

The possible points on a hand equal 24. Only the Master suit scores each turn. The Master suit must be bid for. The Master suit acts as trumps and wins the play but the master suit may only be played if you are void of the led suit. Cerain cards are worth points (Phyliss = 2) (Avery = 1) (Doc = 1) (Skeezix = 3) (Wali = 2) (Pal = 1) Corky = 2) and (each individual trick won = 1)

Name: Munich Decathlon Game
Description: MUNICH DECATHLON Olympic Game. Roll and move game similar to Avalon Hills Decathlon Game except there are no real Decathletes. Each event is scored individually by roll of the dice with the possibility of injuries occurring and then scoring is done similarly to real Decathlon Scoring. This game came out just before the 1972 Olympics and of course was tempered by what happened in Munich in the real games.

Name: All About St. Paul
Description: All About St. Paul is a Monopoly-esque game that was sponsored by the St. Paul Chamber of Commerce, apparently to promote businesses in the city and to acquaint players with how to get around St. Paul and where to find things, c. 1982.  The board is a fairly accurate street map of the city, with various landmarks and businesses depicted on it.  As a bonus to purchasers of the game, a coupon book was also included.

Name: Fight Tournament
Description:
Fight Tournament is about two rival martial arts schools, fighting over 12 rounds in an arena. In each round, the player who commands his fighters best and gets the support of the fans, defeats his opponent.

In each twelve turn players choose a different fighter from his/her team and modifies his/her attack and defense stats with cards to win.

Rules and components are ready to download at http://www.izgames.vze.com/

Name: Vestfirzka kvótasvindlið
Description:
Vestfirzka kvótasvindlið (The Westfjord Quota-swindle) is a humorous game about the fishing industry and fishing quota. The players start the game with a small fishing boat and can buy bigger boats/ships so they can fish more. Selling the catch makes money to buy Quota. Ten Quotas are needed to win the game.

Cards with some actions are included giving bonus or costing the players something, usually money but sometimes just funny things.

Name: Les Batailles de la Fronde
Description: It covers the battles of Bléneau and Faubourg Saint-Antoine (Paris suburbs) during the French Fronde civil war in 1652.

Name: Scene It? To Go!: 80s Music
Description:
From the publisher:
Questions based on 80s music featuring real film clips and trivia questions 
Great travel game-everything you need is enclosed 
Comes with on-screen trivia cards and dice 
Includes 1 game DVD, game board and 4 magnetic tokens 
Requires a DVD player and viewing screen(not included)

Name: Dogfight @ Alam Halfa
Description:
DOGFIGHT @ ALAM HALFA
Rommel's Strike for Cairo, Sept. 1942

Rommel's last offensive in the desert was a compelling one. He knew his past successes were waning for a variety of reasons and that unless
something changed, he would be at the end of his logistical tether. By August, 1942, he was fast approaching a turning point and he feared
his luck might run out. Thus, once he secured promises of adequate fuel supplies that would be delivered by the Italian Navy and Luftwaffe,
this Fox planned for a knock-out blow that some call Gazala II in strategy. A wide sweeping ride though sands of the desert during the
night, a ride some 40 miles in the moonlight to rear of the British forces at Alam Halfa. Rommel chose the night to hide his movements, his
intelligence indicated the mines were nil and no British forces were so far south. The Italian armor divisions, the Littorio and Ariete,
with over 150 M13 tanks (its 47mm gun could knock out most of the British tanks) would help seal the flanks of the 15th and 21st Panzer
Divisions (with over 100 tanks) along with the 90th Division. Rommel was banking on the British performance at Gazala, which showed when
cut off, the British acted in a confused state. Once the pocket was dealt with, each panzer would strike for the Nile, Cairo and
Alexandria. Besides, Hitler insisted Rommel attack.

Each hex is one mile.
AFV units equal 8 AFV
Each turn is 4 hrs.

Name: DVD Spel Van Het Jaar, start-editie
Description:
DVD Spel van het Jaar (translation: DVD Game of the year) is a Dutch quizz boardgame. The game is published by Nova Carta BV in cooperation with the Dutch state television (NOS) ad a Dutch newspaper (De Telegraaf).

The goal of the game is to collect five different ‘DVD-chips’ (blue, green, purple, red and yellow), winner is the player who is the first to do so. The chips can be earned by correctly answering questions from different categories such as sports, politics and showbizz.

A die is used to move the players pawns around the board. If a pawn ends up on a small space, the player is asked a question from one of the cards. When the corect answer is given, the player can roll the die once more and move on. Whenever a pawn ends up on a ‘DVD-space’, the DVD is started and a randomly selected question is played on the TV screen. If the question is answerd correctly, the player recieves a DVD-chip.

A yearly published DVD (starting whith 2007) can be used as an expansion to the base game, but can also be played as a seperate DVD-game.

Name: Gufuushogi
Description: Gufuushogi is a tiny Shogi-inspired abstract that features two radical departures from its namesake: shared pieces and piece rotation. It's played on a 2x3 board with two opposing Kings and two neutral pieces.

Name: Murder Mystery Evening: The Porthole Affair
Description:
Host your own murder mystery evening. An "investigator" narrates the action on CD, which directs the play and sets the mood for a unique dinner party experience. Includes: invitations, host instruction booklet, character booklets, name tags, and themed recipes.

Similar to other murdery mystery games, though in this dinner party style game the action is more scripted.  One player takes the part of the investigator, who narrates the story along with a CD that directs play and sets the mood.

This particular game takes place on the RMS Olympic, the sister ship of the infamous RMS Titanic.

Includes: CD, invitations, host instruction booklet, character booklets, name tags, and themed recipes.
